paper_abstract: A breakthrough in the field of text algorithms was the discovery of the fact that the maximal number of runs in a word of length n is O(n) and that they can all be computed in O (n) time. We study some applications of this result. New simpler O (n) time algorithms are presented for classical textual problems: computing all distinct k-th word powers for a given k, in particular squares for k = 2, and finding all local periods in a given word of length n. Additionally, we present an efficient algorithm for testing primitivity of factors of a word and computing their primitive roots. Applications of runs, despite their importance, are underrepresented in existing literature (approximately one page in the paper of Kolpakov and Kucherov, 1999 [25,26]). In this paper we attempt to fill in this gap. We use Lyndon words and introduce the Lyndon structure of runs as a useful tool when computing powers. In problems related to periods we use some versions of the Manhattan skyline problem. (c) 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Extracting powers and periods in a word from its runs structure
